title: 0 Dipole Moment!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which of the following structures will always have zero dipole moment? "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(\\mu=0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/qno0cd86oG-dipolemoments.png?width=1200"}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We need to look at the structure of the substituents in order to find the dipole moment of each molecule. In cases A, B, C, the substituents of the benzene ring aren't linear, so we can have two geometric isomers in each case. For A, the two isomers are:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/KknVAEaJTg-phenols.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The right isomer has zero dipole moment since all dipole moments cancel out.  However, the left isomer has some non-zero dipole moment, because the component of the dipole moment in -OH add up. Thus, it is possible for A, B, and C to have non-zero dipole moment"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"However, in D, the carbon atoms in the -CN group are sp hybridized, and are therefore linear. 
"},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/CkeY9vyZfr-cn.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since D is symmetric, the dipole moments cancel out, and the net dipole moment of the molecule is zero."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

\langle 2, 1, 3 \rangle \\
\langle 2, 3, 1 \rangle \\
\langle 3, 1, 2 \rangle \\
\langle 3, 2, 1 \rangle
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
If you have 2 distinct items, there are 2 distinct ways to arrange them: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

\langle 2, 1 \rangle
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
If you have 1 distinct item, there is only 1 distinct way to arrange it: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \langle 1 \rangle "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Likewise, there is 1 way to arrange 0 items: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \langle \rangle "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            But at the same time, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is undefined.  Here, we have two conflicting rules, namely "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^0 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^y = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  You could think of this as similar to how "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{x}{x} = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{0}{x} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{0}{0}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which conflicts and is undefined."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Indeed, you could define "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^0 = \frac{x}{x}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and then the undefinedness at "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" matches up.  (Indeed, I would imagine that "},{"type":"text","text":"wheel","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" theorists, if they define exponentiation (at least by a nonnegative integer), would consider that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^0 = \frac{0}{0}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" on this basis.)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Furthermore, you can liken "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" on the intuitive level as well.  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the number of permutations of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" distinct items; "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (for non-negative "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") is the number of possible lists of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" items taken from a set of size "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then we cannot form such a list as there are no items from which to pick, and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^y = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then we have just one possibility which is the empty list, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^0 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  But I realise this does suggest that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^0 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"....

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You are correct that 0! = 1 for reasons that are similar to why
x^0 = 1. Both are defined that way. But there are reasons for these 
definitions; they are not arbitrary."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You cannot reason that x^0 = 1 by thinking of the meaning of powers as 
"repeated multiplications" because you cannot multiply x zero times. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Similarly, you cannot reason out 0! just in terms of the meaning of 
factorial because you cannot multiply all the numbers from zero down 
to 1 to get 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Mathematicians "},{"type":"text","text":"define","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" x^0 = 1 in order to make the laws of exponents 
work even when the exponents can no longer be thought of as repeated 
multiplication. For example, (x^3)(x^5) = x^8 because you can add 
exponents. In the same way (x^0)(x^2) should be equal to x^2 by 
adding exponents. But that means that x^0 must be 1 because when you 
multiply x^2 by it, the result is still x^2. Only x^0 = 1 makes sense 
here."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the same way, when thinking about combinations we can derive a 
formula for "the number of ways of choosing k things from a collection 
of n things." The formula to count out such problems is  n!/k!(n-k)!. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
For example, the number of handshakes that occur when everybody in a 
group of 5 people shakes hands can be computed using n = 5 (five 
people) and k = 2 (2 people per handshake) in this formula. (So the 
answer is 5!/(2! 3!) = 10)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now suppose that there are 2 people and "everybody shakes hands with 
everybody else."  Obviously there is only one handshake. But what 
happens if we put n = 2 (2 people) and k = 2 (2 people per handshake) 
in the formula? We get 2! / (2! 0!).  This is 2/(2 x), where x is the 
value of 0!. The fraction reduces to 1/x, which must equal 1 since 
there is only 1 handshake. The only value of 0! that makes sense here 
is 0! = 1.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And so we define 0! = 1..........................[took help from dr.math forum]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"if it helps,let me know please.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Define the binary operation * such that a*b = 6 for all real numbers a and b.  Note that the operation is associative, among other things."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 * 0 * 0=6."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider this, we can use basic trig functions parentheses and factorials. If you run through each trig function for 0 you'll see it equals 1 for cosine. So now you have 3 1's. So what next? Add them together in parentheses. You now have 3. What operation and make this 3 a 6? Factorial. You now end up with the equation (cos(0)+cos(0)+cos(0))!=6
(1+1+1)!=6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3!=6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3x2x1=6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6=6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I may even have found a solution for two zeros:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lceil exp(\lceil tan(0!)\rceil )\rceil - \lceil tan(0!) \rceil \\
= \lceil exp(2)\rceil - 2 \\
= 8 - 2 \\ 
= 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now some of you might think that the exponential function adds digits to the term, but remember that sin() and cos() are actually also defined by exp(x)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Another solution, not as elegant as the others, using radians:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ceil(tan(cos(0)) + ceil(tan(cos(0))) + ceil(tan(cos(0)))"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Did some cheating using Python to test. :-P"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(ceiling(sec(cos(0!))))^3 - 0! - 0! = 6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"as, 0! =1 -> "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"cos(1) = 0,99... -> "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"sec(0,99)=1,000149... -> "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ceiling(1,000149) = 2 -> "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^3 = 8 -> "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8-1 -1=6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"so, Yes and in the first comment there is the prove why 0! =1 
Nice puzzle !"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" | \lfloor \Gamma ( \ln ( \arctan ( \cos ({0}))) \rfloor | - 0 - 0 = 6 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A little excursion into negative numbers just for the fun of it..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You can buy a tray of avocados at my local fruit shop...3 avocados per tray."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 tray = 3 avocados
2 trays = 6 avocados 
Etc."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So if I bought 0 trays...
That's 0 groups of 3...
Which = 0."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence 0 is technically a multiple of 3!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The standard definition of divisibility (in number theory) is "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Definition. If a and b are integers and there is
some integer c such that a = b · c, then we say
that b divides a or is a factor or divisor of a and
write b|a."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So 3 trivially divides 0 (as do all integers).  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If one were to define "multiple" I can't think of any reason to do so by using divisibility (you can readily modify the above definition to show that multiples can be defined by multiplying), but if you wanted to there is no reason to exclude 0 from the numerator.  Remember the integers aren't a field (i.e. 0|0 is totally legit).

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            By using the notation "Z" you have said a/b is an element of all integers. Firstly, a/b isn't an integer it is a quotient, Q. Secondly, Integers all {..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2,...} so the definition you've used is flawed.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                            That's exactly right - so the answer should be false. In their example of buying trays of avocados they are trying to tell you that nothing would be a multiple - but nothing is nothing so at least to me their example makes no sense.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

In the cases where n is an integer this means that every number (n) is a factor of 0. That's why most (if not all) common definitions of prime number state that it is a number who's only "},{"type":"text","text":"positive","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" factors are 1 and itself. The "},{"type":"text","text":""positive"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" condition is missing from your definition. That's probably what is causing you confusion. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":" Weisstein, Eric W. "Prime Number." From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource. http://mathworld.wolfram.com/PrimeNumber.html"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To Pamela's point, maybe there are some elementary text books that alter the definition to avoid confusion for grade school children. Or maybe there is some change due to the "common core" teaching that is in the news a lot (you know like that example where 5x3 = 3+3+3+3+3 is true but 5x3 = 5+5+5 is false.). But once you get to HS level math and beyond, there is very few people who wouldn't include 0 as a multiple of every number. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":" nd "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pamela Barnes – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I used to like the "challenges" posted on Brilliant, up until the "official" answer given to this idiotic one. This is NOT a trick question, this is NOT PhD level Math, this is just plain wrong. My way of explaining its wrongness in few words? Common definition of prime number: a number whose only factors are 1 and itself; a number, larger than 1, that can only be divided evenly by itself and 1; a positive integer greater than 1 that can only be divided by itself and 1 without leaving a remainder, with 1 often excluded."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"That being said, how is it possible to have prime numbers if 0 is the "third multiple" of every one of them? "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Tom O'Keefe – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Nice. And I was just thinking that I was enjoying our discussion, but you had to blow it. (I pasted the definition from my link. Didn't you see it? And I told you I looked at 6 other online math dictionaries, and only 2 or 3 of those had any definition to look at, and they were inadequate. Not "more like yours". Inadequate.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The original poster used trays of avocados to argue that zero is a multiple of 3. That clearly indicated two things to me: 1) that the author had confused multiple and divisibility, and 2) that the topic under discussion was NOT at a postgraduate level of mathematics."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The common definition of multiple is as I gave it in a previous response, and I found an online math dictionary which agreed (which I hadn't checked before), in addition to my own 30+ years of teaching math at the level of the original question posed (using many textbooks at that level)."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In all common usage of multiple, at the level indicated by the original question and its justification, negatives, fractions, decimals, and zero are not considered multiples of any counting numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For other purposes, the definition can likely be tortured to barely resemble the original meaning, as some of the other posters and you have shown."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But zero is NOT a multiple of 3, at any level of grade school or high school math - the level at which a tray of avocados would be used to illustrate."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thank you for your condescension, but I assure you it is unneeded. If that is representative of the commentary here, perhaps I'll satisfy my math jones elsewhere. Peace."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(Incidentally, you can't use a tray of avocados to illustrate -3 as a multiple of 3.) "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pamela Barnes – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" There's really not much more to say. The link you provided shows a list of problem with no definitions. A simple google search will provide a wealth of referencable results that 0 is a multiple of any number. As well as definition of Least Common Multiple. I would suggest you spend some time sifting through the results and re-familiarize yourself with the concepts. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Tom O'Keefe – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I don't see how that takes care of the difficulty of zero being the LCM of any group of numbers. The definition of LCM is the multiple of least value that a given group of numbers have in common. There is no additional restriction on the value. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Oh, I did find a definition of multiple that agrees:"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"http://www.mathgoodies.com/lessons/vol3/lcm.html"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":""The multiples of a whole number are found by taking the product of any counting number and that whole number.""}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":""Multiple" is just a much more restricted word than many people would like it to be. Which is why my initial answer, False, should be the correct answer. Zero is certainly divisible by 3. But it doesn't follow that zero is then a multiple of 3. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pamela Barnes – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Ahhh, okay, I see your confusion. When you look for the Least Common Multiple, youre evaluating a "},{"type":"text","text":"subset","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" of all multiples. That subset being all positive integers. That doesn't mean that all multiples have to be positive integers. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Tom O'Keefe – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" If I accept that definition of multiple, then zero is a common multiple of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ..."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which would make zero the Least Common Multiple of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ..."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Do you see the problem now?"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The definition of multiple must be restricted to natural numbers. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By the way, I checked about 6 online math dictionaries, and of the 3 that had the word multiple, none had a really usable definition. Certainly not a definition that would allow for the difficulty arising from the LCM. ("98 is a multiple of 7 because you can write 7 x 14 to get it." One mentioned a definition almost like mine, not quite as precise, but used "whole numbers", and because of the imprecision, I wonder if the author is using "whole numbers" correctly.) "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pamela Barnes – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I don't understand what Prime Factorization and Least Common Multiple have to do with the question. The definition of Multiple is: "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":""A multiple of a number x is any quantity y=nx with n an integer. If x and y are integers, then x is called a factor of y." Weisstein, Eric W. "Multiple." From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource. http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Multiple.html"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So applying this definition to the question, we have: y=0; n=0; x=3 0 = 0*3 n:=0 is an integer Therefore 0 is a multiple of 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also, since 0 and 3 are integers, then 3 is a factor of 0. It should be pointed out that Woflram assumes factor to mean integer factor (as the factors include the set of all integers {...-3,-2,-1,0,1,2,3...}. That's probably where the confusion is coming from as in some texts and definitions factors are the set of all positive integers. However, i have yet to come across a definition that contradicts the original question. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Thank you for your response."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I taught Algebra 1 and 2 topics for over 30 years. It's what I learned in my teacher education, and EVERY textbook had it. And like I wrote, "multiple" is related to divisibility, but they are not interchangeable. The prime factorization must include a 3 for multiples of 3, and we don't have prime factorizations of negative numbers. (We can write "complete factorizations", by using -1 as the first factor in the factorization.) And we certainly cannot write a prime factorization of zero."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"An additional difficulty is the Least Common Multiple, which is necessarily a positive number, because the issue doesn't even come up with respect to negative numbers.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Pamela, can you find a source that says that n has to be a natural number?  The common definition states that n has to be an integer.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            NO. The word "multiple" is not interchangeable with divisibility. A multiple of 3 takes the form 3n, where n is a natural (counting) number. I OBJECT to my answer being marked wrong. I expect this to be corrected.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is multiple of "},{"type":"text","text":"b","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"means that,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For example, 6 is multiple of 3. In this case "},{"type":"text","text":"c","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" would be 2.
But 1 is not multiple of 3, because there is no integer "},{"type":"text","text":"c","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" that could make 3 to 1 by multiplying it.
In the same sense, 0 is multiple of 3 because there exist a "},{"type":"text","text":"c","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" that makes 3 to 0 by multiplying it, and that "},{"type":"text","text":"c","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is zero."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 is a multiple of 3 because 3 multiplied by 0 is 0.
So 0 is a multiple of 3."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is quite simple if you don't think about it to hard."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A multiple of a number is any number than can be divided by another number without a remainder."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0÷3=0"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, 0 must be a multiple of 3!
(And technically any integer)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 is a multiple of 3 iff  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 | 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 | 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" iff there exists an integer n for which 3n = 0 is true."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since 0 satisfies this equation, and because 0 is an integer, 0 is a multiple of 3."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\text{True}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" computable? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  refers to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \underbrace{00000 \ldots 0}_{n\, \text{times}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A very important result that will be used in this solution twice is the following: if we have a number of propositions "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_1, A_2, A_3, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that at least one of them is correct (that is, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_1 \vee A_2 \vee A_3 \vee \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is true), and each of these propositions implies the same thing (that is, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_i \rightarrow B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), then the latter thing is true ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is true). When there are two propositions, this is a special case of "},{"type":"text","text":"constructive dilemma","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":". This is obvious when put this way, but its power is when we don't know "},{"type":"text","text":"which","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" of the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" should be true, but we can conclude "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is true regardless."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We claim "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is computable. To see this, note that there are only two cases: either "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (a run of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" consecutive 0's) exists in the decimal representation of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for arbitrarily large "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or there is a greatest integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" exists in the decimal representation of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (but "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^{m+1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" doesn't)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Case 1","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": There are arbitrarily long runs of 0's."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus for any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(n) = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This function is clearly computable: the algorithm simply returns 1 and halts."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Case 2","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": There is a longest run of 0's (and longer ones don't exist)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose that the maximum length is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is also computable: if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \le m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then return 1, otherwise return 0. In either case, the function halts. Note that "},{"type":"text","text":"we don't know what mmm is","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":", but "},{"type":"text","text":"it doesn't matter","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":". This uses the above result; "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the proposition "the longest run of 0's is of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 0's", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the proposition ""},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is computable". Clearly one of the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s is true (from the assumption of the case; if none is true, we have Case 1), and we have just shown "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_i \rightarrow B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is true; "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is computable."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, those two cases are exhaustive, and so we can apply the result again. Either Case 1 or Case 2 is true, but in both cases, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is computable. So the end result is "},{"type":"text","text":"fff is computable","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":", even though we don't actually know which case is true."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            In Case 2, I don't think that the A's imply B.  Just because the longest run of 0's is m does not mean that B is computable, the only way B is computable is if we know what that m is.  Knowing that m exists is not enough.  So in other words, f is computable only if there is either no longest run of 0's or we can compute the longest run of 0's."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For now, I think the answer is we don't know.  My take is that case 1 implies f is computable and case 2 implies f is not computable.  The only way to know which case holds is if you can prove that Pi is normal.  Since we do not yet know if Pi is normal, then we can not know which case holds and thus do not know if f is computable.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
